content.description:
Thinner climbing at the bottom of the climb follows a thin crack up and trending right to a large ledge. From the ledge, climb a really nice hand-size crack trending up and to the left to the anchor. Limited holds outside the crack make hand and foot jams a must!



Farthest right climb in the higher section (up and right) of Crag X. Climbs a great and prominent hand crack on the upper right side of the wall that trends up and left 

SR. Bolted anchors

Juggy, with good protection.



Around the right corner of Upper Crag X.

SR to rappel rings.

Fantastic crack line starting up the center of the main Crag X lower wall, immediately to the left of Center Street. There are two challenging sections, one is in the main crack about half way up the climb. The other was a tricky move out of the starting crack into a larger crack that runs up the left most arete to the finish chains.

Lower Crag X wall, the crack line immediately to the laft of Center Street.
Standard rack up to #2 Camalot.

This climb takes the most prominent of the left angling cracks in the face of the lower Crag X wall. A cruxy finger crack is passed before the cracks zigs to the right and up to a ledge.  This ledge has a chain belay, but the climb continues for another 30 feet so you have the choice of doing it as one pitch or breaking it up. 
  
 Either way, the climb gets harder at this point and the corner crack above the ledge doesn't take good pro until you have made a few moves, but you can protect the moves off the ledge with a .75 camalot in a crack to the right of the corner. 
  
 Very strenuous climbing, but with good, if tough to place, gear finishes the climb up the corner.

Start on a nice little terrace at the base of the lower wall of Crag X, just left of the stacked blocks that form the short crack climb Gord's Block.
A standard rack, with a few doubles of cams in the finger to tight hand sizes and a good selection of small to medium nuts is sufficient.  There is a two bolt rap station at the top.  Double ropes will take you down, otherwise go to the chains on the ledge and make a second rap.  Watch then ends of the rope, even from this intermediate station.

Slab climbing a bolt and thin crack lead to the intermediate anchor of the Gloaming



Obvious thin crack with a bolt on the right of centre street

Single up too 0,75. double on the small size and small nuts

climbs.name: Easter Island
climbs.fa: J. & M. Coope, C. Doig, J. Campbell, P. Croft 1979

content.description:
A fun crack to the right of the main wall of Crag X. The new trail passes right under it so you can't miss it.

Small rack to #3 Camalot

climbs.name: Fingerlickin' Good
climbs.fa: Robin Barley, Peter Shackleton, 1983. FFA Kevin McLane, Jim Campbell, 1983

content.description:
This route climbs the awesome left-leaning finger crack on the upper wall. A few variations exist for accessing the base of the crack. The original route follows the flake-like feature a few meters left of 'Up From Despair'. Protection is good throughout.


Cams, nuts

Good climbing follows a thin crack up to easier climbing above. 



Starts at the bottom right of a large left facing feature in the rock. Climbs up following a small crack (not the right side of the feature) before trending left to the anchor.

SR, bolted anchor

Scramble to a ramp above and right of the start of Centre Street. Clip a black bolt (5.10a) then climb the crack above, eventually trending right to a chain anchor on a ledge. Rap from here or climb the seond pitch crack (5.10b) that leads to the summit.

SR

Very short but sweet thin hand crack. Gymnastic and strenous moves with great protection, slightly overhanging and burly right to the chains. Possible to top rope by scrambling around to the back side of the large block.

Starts a bit to the right of Center Street on a big semi-detached block.
Chain anchors. Two #3 Camalots and one #1 Camalot... you could bring more I suppose.

Mantle onto a ledge and then work a thin crack to an overhanging corner.  Bolted anchor on the slab above the roof.



The far back (damp) corner of the Grunt Wall.

Standard rack.

Climb the bolt line to the left of Easter Island. A tricky bouldery sequence to start and then two hard mantels, an easier but balancy finish.

Left of Easter Island
3 bolts

Climb a leaning groove just left of the Virgin Soil crack to a small roof. Turn it and then slab climb left into X-Ray.



Upper Crag X

4 bolts, SR

Climb a variety of cracks with positive hand and foot holds to a bolted anchor.



Starts on the second, larger, crack to the left of the Grunt corner, which aligns with the edge of the ledge.

Standard rack.  Bolted anchor at top with rap rings.

Boulder problem at the start to low angle climbing.



The obvious bolted route just off the climbers' access trail.

6 bolts to rappel rings.

Climb up a groove up and left, before traversing right to a bolted anchor (shared with Affordable)



Farthest left climb in the higher section (up and right) of Crag X

SR, bolted anchor

Upper Crag X

SR

Beginning at the crack for Out to Lunge, traverse left along a straight left-leaning crack into the final moves of Easter Island. Fun movement, consistently positive & bomber handholds. Smear below the crack.

Purple (0.5) to Blue (#3) Camalots. Placed two red and two green. Bolts with chains at the top.

Out to lunge is the higher of the two traversing cracks to the right of easter island. It starts with a brief right-leaning crack with one move of 10-, then traverses left to its own anchor, independent of Easter Island.

Bolted rappel anchor up top.
Gear up to 1", maybe two .75s for the traverse. Small nut protects the crux well.

climbs.name: Outer Mongolia
climbs.fa: Kevin Duck, Robin Barley, 1981. FFA Peter Croft, Richard Suddaby, 1981

content.description:
Climb the right-trending undercling until you can mantle up and clip a bolt on the slab. Continue up the slab and cracks to a wicked roof crack finish.


2 bolts, standard rack

Climb a short 5.8 hand to finger crack and mantle onto an enormous ledge. Clip a bolt on the left side of the arete and then make bouldery moves off the ledge, firstly on the right side of the arete, but moving left to the crest of the arete at the top. Pull onto a slab and climb easily up to the top ledge. Sling trees for an anchor.

An obvious line but spoiled by the huge ledge midway up which basically turns it into two separate boulder problems. Bolt exists only to prevent groundfall from the second boulder problem if you pitch leftwards off the arete. It doesn't do much to keep you off the ledge, so a pad there can help if you're unwilling to commit. Originally done as a solo with no bolt.

Far right side of Easter island, right of Out to Lunge.
Bottom crack takes gear in the 1" range. The bolt will keep you from grounding but the climb is basically a boulder problem off the upper ledge so you might find a pad on the ledge as useful as the bolt, if not more so.

On the main Crag X wall, climb up the pie shaped piece of rock using the large crack between it and the main wall. At the top of this pie shaped rock is an anchor with rap rings. Past the anchor is another route called Side Street that continues to the very top.

Located on the Main Crag X wall.
No bolts, large gear

Probably not popular because of the awkward, short bolted ending between two great crack climbs. Can be done as a top-rope variation if you've already put up Baby Lizard. 
  
 Start as for that route then step right into the Center Street crack. Climb this - fun laybacking - until it cuts right. Continue up and left following the bolts along a dyke. This cryptic, slabby climbing is obviously a stark contrast to the lower bit. The last move is a very balancy step pretty much level with the anchors.

Center of the main face of Crag X
Gear to 2" plus 3 bolts

This is an extension to Piece of Pie (or PoP is a truncated version of this) on the left side of Crag x.
Full: right facing dihedral, step right to hands/fist shortie forming the pie, clip the anchors, and step right. It is 5.8 to there. Now continue up the discontinuous finger crack up and right through a short steep section before it eases off until the anchors.

Left side of Crag X, belay from ledge
Doubles 0.2-0.75 and nuts. Single 1-4. 3 and 4 can be left out if you're confident at 5.7 fist/hands for 6 ft.

climbs.name: Sniffler
climbs.fa: Randy Atkinson, John Howe, Allen Tate, 1979

content.description:
I found the roof section of this climb to be really fun, and well protected.  The crack widens as you go up into more of an off-width.

After walking by Easter Island area, take the first trail to the left. Continue to veer left, and scramble up a couple rocky sections. Carry on going this way until you get to a treed ledge (where there are anchors for the climbs below - new ones, not sure yet what they are).  At this ledge, there are two parallel 'roof' cracks - Sniffler and Snorter.  Sniffler is the right-hand crack.
Anchor with chains, shared with Snorter.  I'd bring some large cams - BD #3,#4.  I placed a #4 at the roof section and then wished I'd had it higher up.

In my opinion, easier of the two parallel cracks.

After walking by Easter Island area, take the first trail to the left. Continue to veer left, and scramble up a couple rocky sections. Carry on going this way until you get to a treed ledge (where there are anchors for the climbs below - new ones, not sure yet what they are). At this ledge, there are two parallel 'roof' cracks - Sniffler and Snorter. Snorter is the left-hand crack.
SR, anchors with chains at the top

The obvious corner on the far upper right of Upper Crag X where the trail meets the wall. Crux is a bit perplexing down low and significantly easier up top. 


Standard rack.

Climb the shallow curving dihedral on the left of the arete. Thin laybacking and delicate footwork with some tricky gear. There is much to despair. 
  
 Route is on the Upper Crag X wall, head up the new staircase that starts the new smoke bluff connector trail just past Lower Crag X. Upper Crag X area is only 100 feet from the main smoke bluffs trail. 
  
 Starts on the right-most arete on the upper crag X wall, near the trail.

Small nuts and small cams. Bolt anchors.

I nice but slightly tricky hand crack starts the first third of the climb. Followed by a large blocky roof off-wide, this can be climbed directly on the right or around to the left. From the top of this block starts a nice finger crack that climbs up the main face and over a slight bulge, I thought this was the crux. The guidebook says that the route is 22m long, if you climb the easier cracks to the top of the crag it's a full 40m+. Route is on the Upper Crag X wall, head up the new staircase that starts the new smoke bluff connector trail just past Lower Crag X. Upper Crag X area is only 100 feet from the main smoke bluffs trail.
Starts in the obvious hand crack on the left side of the main upper crag X wall. A full assortment of cams and nuts up to #3 C4.

The cliff just right of Boulder Gully, visible from the designated climber's parking area.  With its quick approach, and open faces, it's a good place to go when you're trying to salvage a couple of PM pitches after the rain stops. 
  
 When routes are shown sorted L to R, the lower crag is first, then the upper crag.
